summary: This is a grand jury subpoena issued by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to T-Mobile USA, Inc., requesting telephone records for the period January 1, 2002 through December 31, 2006, as part of an investigation into violations of federal sex trafficking and coercion statutes. The document includes a request for non-disclosure to preserve the confidentiality of the investigation.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.context: Issued the grand jury subpoena and signed the accompanying letter requesting non-disclosure of the subpoena to preserve investigation confidentiality.

persons.name: Geoff E. Berman
persons.role: United States Attorney for the Assistant United States Attorney
persons.context: Signed the grand jury subpoena commanding T-Mobile to produce records and appear before the grand jury.

events.title: Grand Jury Appearance Date
events.description: T-Mobile USA, Inc. is commanded to appear before the Grand Jury for the Southern District of New York to testify and give evidence.

events.title: Subpoena Issued
events.description: The grand jury subpoena is issued to T-Mobile USA, Inc., requesting telephone records from 2002-2006.

locations: Silvio J. Motto Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
T-Mobile USA, Inc. Law Enforcement Relations, 4 Sylvan Way, Parsippany, NJ 07504
United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, Room 220, Borough of Manhattan, City of New York, New York
keyFacts: The subpoena is part of an investigation into alleged violations of 18 U.S.C. §§ 1591 (sex trafficking), 1594(c) (conspiracy to commit sex trafficking), and 2422(b) (coercion and enticement).
The requested records cover a specific five-year period: January 1, 2002 through December 31, 2006.
The U.S. Attorney's Office explicitly requests T-Mobile not to disclose the existence of the subpoena to any third party to preserve the confidentiality of the investigation.
The document indicates the investigation involves a Child Exploitation and Human Trafficking Task Force.
The subpoena demands a wide range of telephonic records including call details, subscriber information, text messages, and IP history.
